Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Large-scale simultaneous multiple alignment and phylogeny estimation
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, a team of investigators will develop new algorithms and software to simultaneously align DNA sequences and reconstruct phylogenetic trees. This methods and theory-oriented project addresses an important problem in phylogenetic reconstruction: relatively poor performance of existing tools in the face of insertions, deletions, and duplications in large datasets. This project will develop a simultaneous approach to DNA sequence alignment and phylogenetic analysis that will allow researchers to overcome these problems. Specific goals for the project will be to develop a portal and open-source software for simultaneous alignment and phylogenetic analysis, develop new simulators to model DNA sequence evolution, establish a working group on alignment methods with the Assembling the Tree of Life (AToL) community, and develop training programs in alignment and phylogeny estimation with outreach activities to minority institutions. The project includes many members of the Cyberinfrastructure for Phylogenetic Research (CIPRES) project and will provide significant new analytic capabilities for that data resource.

By making simultaneous alignment and phylogenetic analysis feasible for very large datasets, this project will provide software tools that will serve a broad community of researchers conducting phylogenetic analyses of DNA sequence data. These tools will enable consideration of DNA regions for phylogenetic analysis that cannot be aligned using existing tools. An open-source, portal interface will open multiple sequence alignment and tree-building to a broader range of users and engagement of existing AToL users will provide input and evaluation early in the software development process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Almost every comparison of more than three species requires researchers to consider the evolutionary relatedness of the species. Thus, estimating evolutionary relationships is a crucial step in biological research. This collaborative research project developed new methods for estimating the genealogical tree of genetic sequences. Most previous methods assume that the alignment is known. An alignment is a statement about which parts of DNA sequences are directly comparable to each other. In reality, the alignment must be inferred from the raw sequence data. Ignoring the fact that one has to estimate the alignment can result in overconfidence in our genealogical estimates. This project developed methods for estimating the evolutionary relationships of sequences when the alignment is not known.

Researchers at the University of Kansas (KU) were responsible for software implementations in this collaborative research project. They produced a new, open-source software tool, SATé, which uses other software tools to repeatedly align sequences and infer ancestry. By considering multiple alignments in the course its operation, SATé can help identify parts of the genealogical tree estimate which are suspicious because they depend on ambiguous parts of the alignment.

A researcher at KU also devised a method for detecting a common artifact in sequence alignments, called "over-alignment", in which the alignment implies too few insertions or deletions. By scoring alternative alignments in the context of a genealogical tree, his method can highlight which columns could be the result of over-alignment.

Researchers funded by this project also extended the software called GARLI in several ways. First, they made GARLI more realistic by allowing it to estimate ancestry under a richer model in which different parts of the genome can evolve under different processes. Next they added a model of DNA sequence evolution to GARLI that allows it to make use of information from insertions and deletions of genetic information. Previously, it had ignored this potentially useful source of information. Finally, GARLI has been extended to consider multiple alignments while it searches for the set of evolutionary relationships that best explain the data. This should make GARLI's tree estimates more robust to errors in alignment.

All software was tested by conducting computer simulation studies. Tutorials for SATé and GARLI were written, published on the web, and demonstrated at scientific conferences to increase the impact of the work. Both tools are distributed under permissive, open-source licenses.

This project helped train an undergraduate student, three graduate students, and three postdoctoral researchers in computational biology, evolutionary biology, and software development.
